channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: Iraqi Militants Kill 26 in Raid on Baghdad Building
item.description: Gunmen stormed an apartment complex known for prostitution and killed at least 20 women and six men, according to the Interior Ministry.
item.dc:creator: By ALISSA J. RUBIN

item.title: Putin and Argentine Leader Agree on Nuclear Power Project
item.description: The Russian president and President Cristina Fernández de Kirchner also discussed cooperation on military technology and satellites.
item.dc:creator: By JONATHAN GILBERT

item.title: Iraqi Militants Kill 26 in Raid on Baghdad Building
item.description: Gunmen stormed an apartment complex known for prostitution and killed at least 20 women and six men, according to the Interior Ministry.
item.dc:creator: By ALISSA J. RUBIN

item.title: Kerry Brokers a Deal to Audit All Afghan Votes
item.description: Secretary of State John Kerry spent a second day in Kabul shuttling between two candidates and the presidential palace to forge an agreement on how to audit recent elections.
item.dc:creator: By CARLOTTA GALL and MATTHEW ROSENBERG
item.media:description: Secretary of State John Kerry looked on as Abdullah Abdullah, a presidential candidate, spoke at a joint news conference Saturday.

item.title: In Inquiry in China, Police Detain Star Anchor
item.description: Rui Chenggang, a prominent state television anchor, was detained by the authorities, furthering recent rumors of a widening government investigation into corruption at China Central Television.
item.dc:creator: By EDWARD WONG
item.media:description: Rui Chenggang, a popular host of a financial news program on China Central Television.

item.title: Sports of The Times: World Cup 2014: Injuries to Mascherano and Neymar Demonstrate Poor Medical Care
item.description: Soccer’s world governing body is apparently indifferent to player safety, especially when it comes to head injuries.
item.dc:creator: By JULIET MACUR
item.media:description: Argentina’s Javier Mascherano returned to play quickly last week after sustaining a head injury.

item.title: Indian Girl’s Rape Called Case of Eye-for-Eye Village Justice
item.description: The rape is the latest in a series of shocking assaults that have drawn attention to remote villages in India, where police precincts are far-flung and traditional forms of justice still dominate.
item.dc:creator: By ELLEN BARRY
item.media:credit: Daniel Berehulak for The New York Times
item.media:description: A 13-year-old girl on Saturday revisited the site in Swang Gulgulia Dhoura, India, where she was raped as punishment for her brother’s alleged assault.

item.title: World Cup Revelry Overwhelms Beloved Neighborhood in São Paulo
item.description: Many revelers described the scene along Vila Madalena’s main drag as “Carnival in Salvador,” as packed, wild and carnal as Brazil’s rowdiest street bacchanal.
item.dc:creator: By SETH KUGEL
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: Fans gathered to watch a World Cup match between Brazil and Colombia in Vila Madalena. Local residents were less enthused.

item.title: U.S. Warns Iran Over ‘Unworkable’ Plans for Nuclear Power Program
item.description: Iran’s supreme leader spoke of a need to dramatically increase nuclear enrichment, while the U.S. and others say the country should be moving toward scaling down.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID E. SANGER

item.title: On Soccer: World Cup 2014: Before Manuel Neuer Was Germany's Keeper, There Was Robert Enke
item.description: Manuel Neuer will be in goal for Germany in Sunday’s World Cup final, but there is a dark side to the lineage of excellent German keepers.
item.dc:creator: By SAM BORDEN
item.media:description: Robert Enke, expected to be Coach Joachim Löw’s first-choice goalkeeper at the 2010 World Cup, committed suicide in 2009. It was later revealed that he had clinical depression.

item.title: Mandalay’s Chinese Muslims Chilled by Riots
item.description: The historical tolerance shown by bygone Buddhist rulers is unraveling in Mandalay, the country’s second largest city, as antipathy between Buddhists and Muslims continues to spread across Myanmar.
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS FULLER

item.title: Opinion: A Refugee Crisis, Not an Immigration Crisis
item.description: They come to our border to escape murder, rape and conscription in the cartels.
item.dc:creator: By SONIA NAZARIO

item.title: Behind German Spy Cases, Twists Worthy of Films
item.description: The close American ally turns a cold shoulder after revelations of espionage, even as both sides acknowledge the urgency of cooperation on global issues.
item.dc:creator: By ALISON SMALE
item.media:description: Chancellor Angela Merkel needs “something” from Washington to save face, a top official says.

item.title: News Analysis: What Is the Role of U.N. Peacekeepers?
item.description: Tensions over the role and pay of United Nations peacekeepers have recently escalated, with deeper grievances just below the surface.
item.dc:creator: By SOMINI SENGUPTA

item.title: U.S. and Iraqis Try to Fragment Extremist Group
item.description: American and Iraqi officials are looking to capitalize on the rifts that are beginning to divide the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria and Sunni militant groups.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By ERIC SCHMITT and ALISSA J. RUBIN
item.media:description: Gen. Martin E. Dempsey, the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, said that the goal was to “enable Iraq” to defend itself.

item.title: Civilians Pay a Price for Gains of Ukraine Forces
item.description: A disputed attack in Marinka, a farming village southeast of Donetsk, killed five civilians and caused anger among residents.
item.dc:creator: By SABRINA TAVERNISE
item.media:description: The remnants of a house that was reportedly struck by Ukraine military bombing in a village near the eastern city of Lugansk.

item.title: World Cup 2014: In Argentina, Lionel Messi Is Not Loved as Much as Diego Maradona
item.description: Lionel Messi has not won over Argentines the way Diego Maradona did, but that may change Sunday in the World Cup final against Germany.
item.dc:creator: By JERÉ LONGMAN
item.media:description: Lionel Messi is a four-time world player of the year.

item.title: Biggest Scorer in World Cup? Maybe Univision
item.description: The huge exposure Univision has received from the World Cup shows how the growth of America’s Hispanic population is reshaping the media landscape.
item.dc:creator: By JONATHAN MAHLER
item.media:credit: Lianne Milton for The New York Times
item.media:description: Edgar Martinez of Univision preparing for a broadcast. The World Cup has set viewing records for the media company.

item.title: As Israel Hits Mosque and Clinic, Air Campaign’s Risks Come Home
item.description: Israel struck a mosque, a center for the disabled and the house of a police commander in Gaza on Saturday. At least 20 people were killed in the strikes, bringing the total number of dead to at least 140, Palestinian officials said.
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN ERLANGER
item.media:description: An Israel Defense Forces map of the mosque that was hit in central Gaza.

item.title: Israel Says It Struck a Gaza Mosque Containing Weapons
item.description: The Israeli military's statement Saturday said that Hamas and Islamic Jihad “systematically use mosques to conceal weaponry and establish underground tunnel networks."
item.dc:creator: By ISABEL KERSHNER

item.title: After Soccer Loss, Dilma Rousseff Soothes Brazil With a Song
item.description: The Brazilian president gave no quarter to opponents who have suggested the country’s humiliating defeat in the World Cup may haunt her in the election this fall.
item.dc:creator: By SIMON ROMERO
item.media:description: President Dilma Rousseff of Brazil in March.

item.title: Remains Thought to Be Those of American Missing in Mexico
item.description: The motorcycle found with a body appears to match that driven by Harry Devert, a former financial trader in New York and the subject of a long search.
item.dc:creator: By DAMIEN CAVE

item.title: Kerry Pushes for Solution to Afghanistan Election Crisis
item.description: Secretary of State John Kerry visited Afghanistan in an effort to resolve an impasse between Abdullah Abdullah and Ashraf Ghani, who each claim to have won the presidency.
item.dc:creator: By MATTHEW ROSENBERG and CARLOTTA GALL
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Demonstrators chained themselves together at the entrance to Kabul’s international airport on Friday to protest election fraud.

item.title: U.S. Knew Britain Planned to Erase Data at The Guardian
item.description: After Britain forced The Guardian to destroy hard drives holding data leaked by Edward J. Snowden, a National Security Agency official called the event “good news,” emails show.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By CHARLIE SAVAGE
item.media:description: Richard H. Ledgett Jr., a National Security Agency official, praised the British government’s destruction of leaked data in The Guardian’s computers.

item.title: Anticipating a Showdown, Ukraine City Empties Out
item.description: While residents flee Donetsk, violence is rising between the military and rebels, who have reportedly used Russian-made rockets to attack Ukrainian soldiers and guards.
item.dc:creator: By SABRINA TAVERNISE
item.media:description: Arsen Pavlov, a rebel fighter, married Elena Kolenkina on Friday in Donetsk, Ukraine, as rebels who control the area killed 19 Ukrainian soldiers and four border guards.
